basics.name: Ding Zhiyu
basics.label: High Performance Computing & Parallel Programming
basics.summary: Ding Zhiyu, from the 'Kite Capital' Weifang, Shandong Province, is a 2023 undergraduate student majoring in Data Science and Big Data Technology at Southwest Petroleum University, currently ranked 1st out of 64 in his major. With a solid foundation in high-performance computing, he is proficient in C/C++, CUDA, MPI/OpenMP and other parallel programming technologies. Through participation in competitions such as the ASC World University Supercomputing Competition, IndySCC@SC24, Marine Computing Challenge, and Operator Development Challenge, he has accumulated rich experience in performance optimization, including ocean simulation parallelization, deep learning operator development, and SpMV algorithm optimization on heterogeneous platforms. He excels at algorithm optimization and performance tuning on CPU/GPU/Sunway and other heterogeneous platforms, possesses excellent problem analysis and solving abilities, and has strong execution capabilities. Currently deepening his study of high-performance computing related technologies, he hopes to continue developing in this field!

education.area: School of Computer Science and Software Engineering, Data Science and Big Data Technology
courses: Big Data Platform Technology and Applications (98), Python (96), Object-Oriented Programming (95)
Principles of Statistics (93), Introduction to Artificial Intelligence (92), Linear Algebra (91), Data Structures and Algorithms (90)

awards.title: ASC2025 World University Supercomputing Competition International Second Prize
awards.summary: The ASC Student Supercomputer Challenge, first held in 2012, is the world's largest supercomputing competition, alongside Germany's ISC and the United States' SC, known as the world's three major supercomputing competitions. This year's AI challenge required teams to run and optimize AlphaFold3 structure prediction code on different computing platforms, testing teams' understanding and optimization capabilities of the AlphaFold3 inference process.

awards.title: Invited to participate in SC24 International Supercomputing Competition Online Track IndySCC
awards.summary: The Supercomputing Conference (SC) is the top conference in the international supercomputing field. IndySCC is the online track established by the SC competition. Like the SC offline track, one of the three major supercomputing competitions, teams must complete given computational tasks within 48 hours under limited conditions and achieve the highest possible computational performance.

awards.title: 2024 Marine Computing Challenge National Finals Third Prize
awards.awarder: China Society for Pacific Studies, Beijing Paratera Technology Co., Ltd.
awards.summary: The Marine Computing Challenge (MCC) covers marine big data processing and analysis, marine environment simulation and prediction, marine resource development and utilization, marine disaster early warning and emergency response, marine artificial intelligence applications and other different application scenarios, comprehensively examining participants' skills in marine application fields.

awards.title: Tecorigin Operator Development Challenge National Finals Third Prize
awards.awarder: Second OpenAtom Contest - OpenAtom Open Source Foundation
awards.summary: The Tecorigin Operator Development Challenge is based on the Teco-AL (Taichu Acceleration Library) unified operator library model, using SDAA C programming language for operator performance optimization on the Taichu domestic GPU platform. The competition covers core deep learning operator optimization including tecoalArgmax, tecoalActivationBackward, tecoalConvolutionForward, examining participants' high-performance computing technical capabilities in parallel computing, memory access optimization, and vector instruction optimization under domestic GPU architecture.

awards.title: Tianyi Cloud Xi Rang Cup College AI Competition Sichuan Province Second Place
awards.awarder: China Telecom Group Co., Ltd., Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd.
awards.summary: The Tianyi Cloud Xi Rang Cup College AI Competition operator optimization track, based on Ascend NPU platform using AscendC for operator development and performance optimization. The competition covers high-performance implementation of core deep learning operators such as NLLLossGrad backward operator and QuantBatchMatmul+Swiglu fusion operator, examining key technologies such as multi-core parallelism, Cube/Vector pipeline optimization, and memory management under Ascend 910B architecture. The competition focuses on fine-grained operator optimization of domestic heterogeneous computing infrastructure, promoting innovative applications of high-performance computing in the CANN ecosystem.

awards.title: 15th Blue Bridge Cup National Finals Third Prize
awards.awarder: Ministry of Industry and Information Technology Talent Exchange Center, Blue Bridge Cup Competition Committee
awards.summary: Blue Bridge Cup Competition Python Programming Group. This competition covers basic algorithms, data structures, dynamic programming, graph theory, string processing, mathematical computation and other question types, requiring completion of multiple programming problems within limited time under OI competition format, focusing on examining participants' ability to solve algorithmic problems using Python language.

awards.title: Invited to participate in 2024 Tencent Kaiwu AI Global Open Competition Invitational
awards.awarder: 2024 Tencent Kaiwu AI Global Open Competition Committee
awards.summary: Participated in the 2024 Tencent Kaiwu AI Global Open Competition Invitational, successfully completed the 'AIPC High-Performance Gaming Track'.

awards.title: Outstanding Student First-Class and Second-Class Scholarships

projects.name: Parallel Computing Optimization Based on Oil Spill Prediction Model
projects.description: This project was selected from the 2024 Marine Computing Challenge finals. Using a self-developed two-dimensional oil spill prediction model, under the premise of ensuring understanding of the Euler method for solving trajectory equations and the correctness of vector-based judgment of whether oil particles adhere to the shore, parallel computing technology was utilized to accelerate the program.
highlights: Responsibilities: Through implementing MPI and OpenMP hybrid parallelization on the original serial program and adopting load balancing techniques, I fully utilized the 2-node 128-core computing resources to improve algorithm execution efficiency. For memory access optimization, we used Fortran/C to rearrange data access order, utilizing memory locality to improve cache hit rates. For communication optimization, I used non-blocking communication, packed data communication, and other optimization methods. We also used algorithm-level optimization techniques such as fast exclusion of non-intersecting line segments and binary search to quickly determine the relationship between oil particle trajectories and coastlines.

Project Results: Passed correctness verification through test cases provided by the organizing committee. On the initial test case, compared to the baseline, achieved approximately 2482.14x speedup, ranking fifth among finalist teams and winning the national third prize.

projects.name: AlphaFold3-based Protein Structure Prediction Inference Optimization Project
projects.description: Selected from the ASC25 World University Supercomputing Competition, this project focuses on inference performance optimization of Google DeepMind's AlphaFold3 protein structure prediction model. The project requires minimizing inference time on both GPU and CPU platforms while maintaining prediction accuracy, processing 12 protein sequence samples of different lengths, involving complex diffusion model architecture and JAX deep learning framework optimization.
highlights: Responsibilities: Completed AlphaFold3 environment deployment on NVIDIA A100 GPU and Intel Xeon CPU hybrid architecture, identified inference bottlenecks through cProfiler performance analysis tools, discovering that JAX framework JIT compilation consumed significant time. For GPU optimization, implemented strategies including disabling Triton GEMM compilation and optimizing compilation bucket parameters; for CPU optimization, resolved numerical computation precision issues in the diffusion_head.py module, fixed NaN errors caused by negative number square roots, and adopted epsilon numerical stability techniques to ensure computational accuracy.

Project Results: Successfully achieved significant AlphaFold3 inference acceleration, with GPU optimization achieving 1.2-2.4x performance improvement across different sequence lengths, and CPU optimization achieving 1.1-5.3x speedup, particularly effective on short sequences. Through systematic compilation optimization and algorithmic tuning, while ensuring protein structure prediction confidence values consistent with baseline code, provided efficient inference solutions for AlphaFold3 applications in bioinformatics and drug design fields.

projects.name: NAMD-based Molecular Dynamics Simulation Performance Optimization Challenge
projects.description: Selected from IndySCC@SC24 International Supercomputing Student Cluster Competition, this project focuses on large-scale molecular dynamics simulation optimization for biomolecular systems. The project covers multi-level biological computing challenges including water molecule physical property analysis, protein folding dynamics, and thermodynamic integration free energy calculations, requiring efficient simulation of systems ranging from 100,000 to 20 million atoms within a limited 48-hour timeframe.
highlights: Responsibilities: Completed NAMD environment deployment and GPU acceleration configuration on Jetstream2 cloud platform, implemented various molecular dynamics simulation algorithms including extended adaptive biasing force method (eABF), replica exchange molecular dynamics, thermodynamic integration and other advanced sampling techniques, optimized time step from 2fs to 4fs through hydrogen mass repartitioning technique, adopted GPU parallel computing strategies to handle complex task scheduling for simultaneous multi-replica execution.

Project Results: Successfully completed precise calculations of water molecule heat capacity and diffusion coefficients, achieved convergent calculation of deca-alanine protein α-helix folding free energy curves, reached approximately 15 nanoseconds/day simulation performance on A100 GPU, significantly improved computational efficiency of large-scale biomolecular systems while maintaining computational accuracy through algorithmic optimization.

projects.name: MLPerf Inference-based BERT Model Inference Performance Optimization
projects.description: Selected from the IndySCC24 International Supercomputing Competition MLPerf Inference benchmark testing challenge, this project focuses on inference performance optimization of the BERT-99 large language model on question-answering tasks (Squad v1.1 dataset). The project requires efficient inference implementation on CPU and GPU heterogeneous platforms, using MLCommons CM automation framework for benchmark testing configuration and result submission, involving core technologies such as deep learning inference optimization, parallel computing, and performance tuning.
highlights: Responsibilities: Deployed MLPerf environment on AMD EPYC 7713 CPU and NVIDIA A100 GPU hybrid architecture, overcoming technical challenges such as permission configuration and file packaging. Designed and implemented batch inference optimization strategies, including multi-input sample batch collection, data preprocessing pipeline reconstruction, GPU parallel inference acceleration, and result post-processing optimization. Through in-depth analysis of inference bottlenecks, reconstructed the issue_queries method to implement batch data preparation, optimized the process_batch method to improve GPU utilization, achieving end-to-end inference performance optimization.

Project Results: Successfully achieved significant BERT inference performance improvement, with GPU inference throughput reaching 85.447 samples/second, a 26.8x improvement compared to CPU's 3.193 samples/second. Through batch processing optimization techniques, improved GPU utilization from baseline test's 54% to 97%, significantly reducing inference latency while maintaining 90.876% accuracy. Project results were successfully submitted to GitHub and verified by MLCommons officials.

projects.name: PCG Algorithm Optimization Based on New Generation Sunway Supercomputer
projects.description: Project Brief: Selected from the preliminary round of the 7th Domestic CPU Parallel Application Challenge, optimizing the Preconditioned Conjugate Gradient (PCG) algorithm for many-core architecture.
highlights: Responsibilities: For the core hotspot SpMV algorithm, adopted approximately balanced row partitioning strategy, LDM space memory access adjustment and other optimization methods; analyzed the workflow, utilized main core to hide partial computation, making full use of LDM space.
Project Results: Passed correctness verification, achieved an average speedup of 30x
